>BTW, I wouldn't be surprised if stone anvils were used at the time for 
>practical rather than aesthetic reasons.  Large pieces of iron would have 
>been very expensive but large rocks were free except for the lifting, 
>hauling and dressing.  I've read some speculation somewhere about stone 
>anvils having an influence on early sword steel patterns.  When it comes to 
>finish work on tsuba it's easier to make and use a stone texture punch than 
>trying to hammer on a stone get the texture.  If anyone wants to make such 
>a punch, all it takes is a cheap propane torch, a rod of tool steel, a rock 
>and a hammer.  I can tell you how to do it.
>
>Jim
>   Would love to find out if they did indeed use
>   an irregular hammer and anvil in the old days, I wonder if anyone else
>   could give us some more thoughts on this?
